content:
The phrase "Your friend uses dating apps and is sick of having to go through multiple group photos to figure out which person holds the account" could be clearer. A more precise phrasing might be "to identify the account owner in group photos," as the word "holds" does not read well in this context.

The phrase "figure out the person who is in all of the photos and output their description" is somewhat awkwardly phrased. A simpler alternative is: "Identify the person who appears in all photos and output their description."

The phrase "If there are multiple people who appear in all photos or there is no-one who appears in all photos then print Catfish Alert!" could be interpreted in several ways.

Suggested revision: "Output the description of the person who appears in all photos. If no single unique person appears in every photo, print 'Catfish Alert!'"

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: An interesting clash about determining the common link.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash, thanks for not spoiling the solution.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great clash, might be a bit harder for the new dev out there but still fun to do.
I think it should be noted that descriptions for each user maintain the same order across photos (which is the case in all of these examples IIRC)

For the non-catfish cases, "the only person" is the only person which appears in all photos, and all the other people appears at most in 1 photo. Would you consider adding cases where the other people appears more than once but still not in all photos? For example:

4 photos
A;B
A;B;C
A;C;D
A;B;D

Answer: A

Thanks.

Hopefully this is well-received and of reasonable difficulty for a clash. I'm not sure how hard it is to parse the inputs for C-like languages though... I also tried to reduce the number of "Catfish" results to prevent people just submitting "Print('Catfish Alert!')" and getting a decent score. Also, I have disabled Reverse as I don't think it's nice to reverse engineer a clash with such hard-to-read inputs, but happy to hear counter-arguments.

Here's some code I wrote to generate the test cases, in case anyone is interested:
https://ato.pxeger.com/run?1=dVLLbtswEAR65FdMZBSQHEuwempaKEXR3ttDb6oQ0BJlEqYolY8IgaMv6SWH5qf6NV1FduBLL-Q-ZofD3f39x4bdw9PTc_Bt-v7vG2WKG9agQJxnWZZvE2CF6xxtb-GlQN1bK2oPbtworINqEVAUyBlddLri7Vh-51rgBzdGNPim1b1I3UG9eF-5PZydiskZ7GRvPTrRqNClUqi99PBc64qNc9pLZaAFN6iDvX-oWD1Hd7YfDXa6N42AJeKd5vUB_wvrIDAoc8DeCmEwBDtoUbGWJKe3OJYuc7yj0Aby1RpfrWhUXmJ1rE-RCZIrG1XriHIT2BC8g2Gc2NqyYqobyAq4xRafEIc0TzKvOuGyjg_HGYIJH0DXCoTtnRc2dglznsrMBbTJfH_Hz48yN3fY-cyFjlF_5hnFLqzfXbIT-ZQFo36lJa-ScruBCxXr7X4pnSGP6hHc2kUijYw0ElvmpGp9rBJco1yTrA14RSovUwxzIbmhbWnA0_JxIn_hvcvX0cfoFIx-GmrOshnzA8QUfeG-VU7isxbWX0XLxp0W77yA_wA

If you want to ease the parsing in C you could:

- Replace "with #{color} hair" with just color (so we can use the space as delimiter)
- Add the number of people described per photo as argument (assuming this varies per photo, otherwise just give it once at the beginning)
- Remove the commas
- (and probably ask for a solution without commas too. Also, newline separated is easier.)

And I'm assuming that the details per person is always 4.

Then:

2
Pale, tall, thin, with brown hair;Dark-skinned, short, thin, with brown hair
Dark-skinned, short, thin, with brown hair;Dark-skinned, tall curvy, with brown hair

becomes 
2
2
Pale tall thin brown
Dark-skinned short thin brown
2
Dark-skinned short thin brown
Dark-skinned tall curvy brown (*)

(*) I think you are lacking a ',' after tall here in your test.

And if the number of people per photo is constant

2 2
Pale tall thin brown
Dark-skinned short thin brown
Dark-skinned short thin brown
Dark-skinned tall curvy brown

The stub could be:

read nPhotos:int nDescriptions:int
loop nPhotos loop nDescriptions loop 4 read description:word(100)
write sole_common_description or Catfish Alert!

STATEMENT
Dating App: Which One Are You?!! by StepBack13
That's a good point. Thanks for the insight as always. I'll add a final test/validator pair where this level of scrutiny is needed.

Yes, I've mentioned it in the constraints:
"Descriptions always consist of 4 parts {Skin tone, height, shape, hair colour}" but I'll also emphasise it now in {{CONSTANT}} formatting.
Thanks, great suggestions. Edited them all in. I'm glad you've made it easier to read and understand with your edits.

Thank you. Could there still be another additional pair of cases where:
* there are fewer people,
* there are fewer photos, and
* **everyone** appears more than once (yet there's no catfish)?

This will serve as an easier case for players to understand the requirement better.
Cool, good idea and best to have at least 2 pairs that have this kind of complexity. Test/Validator 6 now do as you requested, and I didn't remove any of the old T/V pairs, just shifted them down. :)
Minor point: Test 7 is similar to Validator 8, and Test 8 is similar to Validator 7 now ðŸ˜‰

Well spotted, I'm always bound to mix something up when I try to shift the order around. Fixed it now so that the former Validators 7/8 are now 8/7.

I wish CG would allow you to insert a new test/validator pair at any position in the order. :P

Hmmm, thanks for the explanation.
It seems like adding the per-line loop indicators will be too annoying for other languages that don't need them, but I'll see about at least making the hair description into a single word like "red-hair" or "blonde-hair" when I have time.
You could also set on a fixed number (variable across tests) if you reach to the conclusion that it doesn't take away anything relevant from the task. Much like the last example / stub I wrote.
